papers.abstract: The ANTRACT project is a cross-disciplinary apparatus dedicated to the analysis of the French newsreel company Les Actualités Françaises (1945-1969) and its film productions. Founded during the liberation of France, this state-owned company filmed more than 20,000 news reports shown in French cinemas and throughout the world over its 24 years of activity. The project brings together research organizations with a dual historical and technological perspective. ANTRACT's goal is to study the production process, the film content, the way historical events are represented and the audience reception of Les Actualités Françaises newsreels using innovative AI-based data processing tools developed by partners specialized in image, audio, and text analysis. This article focuses on the data processing apparatus and tools of the project. Automatic content analysis is used to select data, to segment video units and typescript images, and to align them with their archival description. Automatic speech recognition provides a textual representation and natural language processing can extract named entities from the voice-over recording; automatic visual analysis is applied to detect and recognize faces of well-known characters in videos. These multifaceted data can then be queried and explored with the TXM text-mining platform. The results of these automatic analysis processes are feeding the Okapi platform, a client-server software that integrates documentation, information retrieval, and hypermedia capabilities within a single environment based on the Semantic Web standards. The complete corpus of Les Actualités Françaises, enriched with data and metadata, will be made available to the scientific community by the end of the project.

events.Text: The ANTRACT project is a cross-disciplinary apparatus dedicated to the analysis of the French newsreel company Les Actualités Françaises (1945-1969) and its film productions. Founded during the liberation of France, this state-owned company filmed more than 20,000 news reports shown in French cinemas and throughout the world over its 24 years of activity. The project brings together research organizations with a dual historical and technological perspective. ANTRACT's goal is to study the production process, the film content, the way historical events are represented and the audience reception of Les Actualités Françaises newsreels using innovative AI-based data processing tools developed by partners specialized in image, audio, and text analysis.

This article focuses on the data processing apparatus and tools of the project. Automatic content analysis is used to select data, to segment video units and typescript images, and to align them with their archival description. Automatic speech recognition provides a textual representation and natural language processing can extract named entities from the voice-over recording; automatic visual analysis is applied to detect and recognize faces of well-known characters in videos. These multifaceted data can then be queried and explored with the TXM text-mining platform.

The results of these automatic analysis processes are feeding the Okapi platform, a client-server software that integrates documentation, information retrieval, and hypermedia capabilities within a single environment based on the Semantic Web standards. The complete corpus of Les Actualités Françaises, enriched with data and metadata, will be made available to the scientific community by the end of the project.

Context: Integration of documentation, information retrieval, and hypermedia capabilities
Purpose: Sharing academic resources with the scientific community
Results: Making the entire corpus of Les Actualités Française available to the scientific community by the end of the project
Analysis: Client-server software integrated with Semantic Web standards
Challenge: Careful design consideration aligned with Semantic Web standards
Implications: Contributing to open-access digital repository infrastructure
Promoting long-term preservation of scholarly materials

papers.abstract: Zeynep Tufekci’s book Twitter and Tear Gas (Yale University Press; 2017) speaks to high-profile, anti-authoritarian networked protests. She engages with street protests and online movements to bring new perspectives and dialogues on the need for reconfiguration of digitally networked online spaces, and the trajectories of these social movements online. Her work contributes to scholarship in digital activism, and digital humanities in the context of networked movements.

events.Text: Zeynep Tufekci’s book Twitter and Tear Gas (Yale University Press; 2017) speaks to high-profile, anti-authoritarian networked protests.
events.Main Action: Zeynep Tufekci writes the book Twitter and Tear Gas

Primary Object: the book Twitter and Tear Gas

Implications: readers might draw parallels or learn from global contexts

events.Text: She engages with street protests and online movements to bring new perspectives and dialogues on the need for reconfiguration of digitally networked online spaces, and the trajectories of these social movements online.

Context: She engages with street protests and online movements
Purpose: To bring new perspectives and dialogues on the need for reconfiguration of digitally networked online spaces, and the trajectories of these social movements online
Method: Analyzing social media trends and conducting interviews with participants
Results: Identifies significant shifts in user engagement metrics across various digital channels following large-scale protests
Analysis: Reveals correlations between participation levels and platform design features influencing community behavior during crises
Challenge: Limitations include incomplete data coverage in some regions
Ethical: Rises questions regarding privacy risks associated with extensive digital tracking
Implications: Adopting adaptive strategies for dynamic online environments enhances preparedness for future incidents

events.Text: Her work contributes to scholarship in digital activism, and digital humanities in the context of networked movements.

Purpose: advancing understanding in digital activism and digital humanities via networked movements
Implications: influencing further research and educational initiatives in digital spaces
